title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for correctly identifying In−(aq) as the predominant form in the aqueous layer of beaker Y because the solution is not acidic (may be implicit).

1 point is earned for stating that pH > pKa and that this causes the equilibrium to favor the products

The conjugate base form, In−(aq), is the predominant form of the indicator in the aqueous pH 7 buffer in beaker Y. This is because the pH is greater than the pKa of HIn, causing the equilibrium to form a significant amount of products, In-(aq) and H3O+(aq).
descriptions:
The student response earns none of the following points:

1 point is earned for correctly identifying In−(aq) as the predominant form in the aqueous layer of beaker Y because the solution is not acidic (may be implicit).

1 point is earned for stating that pH > pKa and that this causes the equilibrium to favor the products

The conjugate base form, In−(aq), is the predominant form of the indicator in the aqueous pH 7 buffer in beaker Y. This is because the pH is greater than the pKa of HIn, causing the equilibrium to form a significant amount of products, In-(aq) and H3O+(aq).

The student response earns one of the following points:

1 point is earned for correctly identifying In−(aq) as the predominant form in the aqueous layer of beaker Y because the solution is not acidic (may be implicit).

1 point is earned for stating that pH > pKa and that this causes the equilibrium to favor the products

The conjugate base form, In−(aq), is the predominant form of the indicator in the aqueous pH 7 buffer in beaker Y. This is because the pH is greater than the pKa of HIn, causing the equilibrium to form a significant amount of products, In-(aq) and H3O+(aq).

The student response earns two of the following points:

1 point is earned for correctly identifying In−(aq) as the predominant form in the aqueous layer of beaker Y because the solution is not acidic (may be implicit).

1 point is earned for stating that pH > pKa and that this causes the equilibrium to favor the products

The conjugate base form, In−(aq), is the predominant form of the indicator in the aqueous pH 7 buffer in beaker Y. This is because the pH is greater than the pKa of HIn, causing the equilibrium to form a significant amount of products, In-(aq) and H3O+(aq).

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for explaining the yellow color in the oil layer of beaker X in terms of acid-base equilibrium and interparticle forces between HIn molecules and oil molecules.

1 point is earned for explaining the colorless oil layer of beaker Y in terms of interparticle forces between In− ions and water molecules.

At pH 3 the acid form HIn(aq) predominates in the aqueous layer of beaker X because pH < pKa. Since HIn(aq) is a neutral molecule, some of it can dissolve in the oil layer of beaker X because of London dispersion interactions with the oil, causing the oil layer to be yellow.

Since In−(aq) is charged, it will preferentially dissolve in the aqueous layer of beaker Y because of ion-dipole interactions with the water, leaving the oil layer colorless.
descriptions:
The student response earns none of the following points:

1 point is earned for explaining the yellow color in the oil layer of beaker X in terms of acid-base equilibrium and interparticle forces between HIn molecules and oil molecules.

1 point is earned for explaining the colorless oil layer of beaker Y in terms of interparticle forces between In− ions and water molecules.

At pH 3 the acid form HIn(aq) predominates in the aqueous layer of beaker X because pH < pKa. Since HIn(aq) is a neutral molecule, some of it can dissolve in the oil layer of beaker X because of London dispersion interactions with the oil, causing the oil layer to be yellow.

Since In−(aq) is charged, it will preferentially dissolve in the aqueous layer of beaker Y because of ion-dipole interactions with the water, leaving the oil layer colorless.

At pH 3 the acid form HIn(aq) predominates in the aqueous layer of beaker X because pH < pKa. Since HIn(aq) is a neutral molecule, some of it can dissolve in the oil layer of beaker X because of London dispersion interactions with the oil, causing the oil layer to be yellow.

Since In−(aq) is charged, it will preferentially dissolve in the aqueous layer of beaker Y because of ion-dipole interactions with the water, leaving the oil layer colorless.

The student response earns two of the following points:

1 point is earned for explaining the yellow color in the oil layer of beaker X in terms of acid-base equilibrium and interparticle forces between HIn molecules and oil molecules.

1 point is earned for explaining the colorless oil layer of beaker Y in terms of interparticle forces between In− ions and water molecules.

At pH 3 the acid form HIn(aq) predominates in the aqueous layer of beaker X because pH < pKa. Since HIn(aq) is a neutral molecule, some of it can dissolve in the oil layer of beaker X because of London dispersion interactions with the oil, causing the oil layer to be yellow.

Since In−(aq) is charged, it will preferentially dissolve in the aqueous layer of beaker Y because of ion-dipole interactions with the water, leaving the oil layer colorless.
